ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained exposure to a variety of Near Eastern texts.

I gained knowledge of many foundational texts from the Middle East. More importantly, I learned how to compare these texts, both across various cultures of the Middle East as well as across wide ranges of time.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
The strength of the course was the reading material that was selected as well as the professor, Dr. Hodgkin. Dr. Hodgkin is an engaging speaker whose passion for the material was evident and infectious. While I respect Dr. Hodgkin's attempt to run the class as a seminar, encouraging students to lead discussions and break-off into smaller group discussions, I would have appreciated hearing more from Dr. Hodgkin. I realize that due to time constraints, Dr. Hodgkin chose to allocate as much class time as possible to reading the texts; however, as an introductory course, the class would have benefitted from more context provided for the reading material.  The information that Dr. Hodgkin offered was always fascinating--often from his first-hand experience and personal travels in the Middle East. His knowledge of the material, supplemented by his personal anecdotes was the highlight of the course. While he encouraged multiple interpretations of texts, it was clear from Dr. Hodgkin's comments that he often had an alternative point-of-view which I wish he would have shared. 

I would also recommend eliminating the Film component from the class syllabus and re-allocating the time to the texts all of which were deserving of more time.

Strengths: I really liked the texts that were selected for reading. I appreciated how we were not confined to one particular area or time period of the Middle East. I also really liked how Sam led seminars, encouraging us to speak in class and to be unafraid to make mistakes. Lastly, I appreciated how Sam took us to professional talks at the MacMillan Center.
Weakness: Sometimes it was not entirely clear what our readings were until a day or two before class. I wish we had more notice for some of these readings, but I understand this was Sam's first time teaching the course and thus the syllabus was bound to be a bit loose.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to another student who wants to learn about the literature and culture of the Middle East. I will say, this course spends more time in the past than in the present, so bear that in mind.
